In research context: Chip-and-PIN systems offer several security features that make them more secure than traditional magnetic stripe technology. Firstly, chip-and-PIN systems use encryption methods such as EMV (Europay, Mastercard, Visa) to secure transactions. This means that sensitive information such as credit card numbers and PINs are protected from interception and eavesdropping. Additionally, the chip on the credit card contains a secure element that performs cryptographic calculations, making it more difficult to skim or clone the card. Furthermore, the PIN adds an extra layer of security, as it requires the cardholder to enter a unique code to authenticate transactions. This makes it more difficult for hackers to use stolen credit cards for unauthorized transactions. On the other hand, traditional magnetic stripe technology is more vulnerable to skimming and cloning, as the information is stored in plain text on the magnetic stripe.
